name: Fourth Crusade
summary: The Fourth Crusade was launched in 1202 with the intention of recapturing Jerusalem. However, the crusade was diverted to Constantinople, which was sacked in 1204. This event deepened the schism between Eastern and Western Christianity and established the Latin Empire of Constantinople. The crusade never reached the Holy Land.

name: Sack of Constantinople (1204)
summary: The Sack of Constantinople occurred in 1204 when the Fourth Crusade diverted from its original goal and attacked the Byzantine capital. The city was brutally sacked, with many churches and monasteries looted. This event further deepened the schism between Eastern and Western Christianity and weakened the Byzantine Empire.

name: Albigensian Crusade
summary: The Albigensian Crusade was a 20-year military campaign initiated by Pope Innocent III to eliminate the Cathar heresy in southern France. The crusade resulted in the destruction of the Cathar movement and the integration of the Languedoc region into the Kingdom of France. It was one of the most brutal crusades, marked by massacres and the destruction of entire cities.

name: Fourth Lateran Council
summary: The Fourth Lateran Council was convened by Pope Innocent III in 1215. It was one of the most important councils of the Middle Ages and addressed numerous issues including Church reform, the definition of transubstantiation, annual confession, and the organization of crusades. The council also established regulations for Jews and Muslims and strengthened papal authority.

name: Fifth Crusade
summary: The Fifth Crusade was launched in 1217 with the goal of conquering Egypt as a stepping stone to recapturing Jerusalem. The crusaders captured the port city of Damietta but were eventually forced to retreat after a failed attack on Cairo. The crusade ended in failure, though it did result in a temporary truce with the Ayyubid sultan.

name: Sixth Crusade
summary: The Sixth Crusade was led by Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II. Through diplomacy rather than military force, Frederick II negotiated the return of Jerusalem, Bethlehem, and Nazareth to Christian control for ten years. This was the most successful crusade since the First Crusade, though it was achieved through treaty rather than conquest.

name: Seventh Crusade
summary: The Seventh Crusade was led by King Louis IX of France (St. Louis). The crusade targeted Egypt, with the goal of using it as a base to recapture Jerusalem. The crusaders captured Damietta but were decisively defeated at the Battle of Mansurah. Louis IX was captured and had to pay a large ransom for his release. The crusade ended in failure.

name: Papal Inquisition Established
summary: The Papal Inquisition was formally established by Pope Gregory IX in 1231 to combat heresy. The Inquisition was initially focused on the Albigensian heresy in southern France but later expanded. It was administered by Dominican and Franciscan friars and became a permanent institution of the Church for dealing with heresy.
